subject: core: Add TX/RX API that exposes message tag and tag owner
commitMessage:
core: Add TX/RX API that exposes message tag and tag owner

MCTP received packets can carry a message tag and tag owner bit
which is set by a remote MCTP endpoint. This can be used by the
remote MCTP endpoint to track the responses. Thus, libmctp should
provide a mechanism for the upper layer MCTP applications to
respond with the same message tag.

This patchset extends TX and RX API with message tag and
tag owner bits.

Signed-off-by: Sumanth Bhat <sumanth.bhat@linux.intel.com>
Change-Id: I6d07eafa86c653abdd4313ab7cc77e5a93124477

Looks good to me, just a couple of minor things inline.

I suspect the tx side might be the tricky bit though - do you want to merge those two changes as one? Or is it useful to have just the RX side included?

I'm wondering whether we just tag a new version then break the API of the current callback so we don't have two. For downstream projects consuming the source it will yield a compilation failure so it's obvious that something is broken at the point of integration. Anyone using the current callback can just ignore the additional parameters and carry on. On OpenBMC it's only the tools in this repo that link against it to the best of my knowledge, so despite the fact that there's also an ABI break everything should be coherent.
Yep, I'd be OK with this approach too, and it avoids potential for strange semantics when a user attempts to set both callbacks.
I plan to submit a separate patch for the TX path
Made changes, there is only one API now and it is going to be incompatible with previous builds.
will correct this in next patchset.
Please use consistent formatting here (and on the next hunk): opening brace on the same line as the condition.
Comment is no longer applicable - removed this hunk altogether.
Just to keep this consistent with the _fn suffix (and maybe a bit shorter), can we call this mctp_rx_tag_fn ?
Comment no longer applicable, extended the old API.
Since this will break upstream PLDM API calls into libmctp, what is the plan for PLDM fixups? That would have to be done once this is close to merge?

Since upstream PLDM does not consume message tag & tag owner yet, we could just modify the TX and RX APIs in PLDM to the new extended API, and msg_tag and tag_owner will be unused parameters in PLDM. This can be done when this is close to the merge. Usage of these parameters can be done subsequently.

My first proposal was to have 2 different APIs (check patchset 1) which will give a "deprecation" time for other repos to adopt to new API. 

I am okay with either approach, but with the breaking API, we will have to merge PLDM and MCTP together.
Where does the pldm stack link against libmctp? Can someone give me a link?

Upstream PLDM does not link against libmctp; Deepak is talking about exposing the message tags & tag owner through sockets I believe (PLDM needs to consume message tags and tag owner bits eventually).
But this change won't break that. The socket ABI is a separate problem. For now we can move what tag/TO maintenance code we have into mctp-demux-daemon, right?
Andrew, Sumanth - what I meant was: once we make this API change and say PLDM doesn't provide tag information through the socket, would that break something?
This one won't break PLDM since mctp-demux-daemon will not do anything with the tag/TO.
Have you tried implementing this? I'm feeling we should implement it in the same patch that adjusts the Rx API for coherence.
Ah, I saw your comment after pushing this : https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/libmctp/+/50323/1. May be we can merge them together?
Thanks Sumanth. Sorry it's taken a while to take a look but I've finally got there. Mostly a bunch of nitpicks.

I'd prefer we put msg_tag and tag_owner after dest and before buf. This way it at least vaguely represents the MCTP header.

I'd also put tag_owner before msg_tag as this way it reads the same left-to-right as the header bit ordering in the spec. If nothing else just for pedantic consistency :)
The parameter order is different here to mctp_rx(), though is more aligned with what I was advocating above.
We're using kernel-style C here, so single-line conditional bodies don't use curly braces.
We already know it conforms to the mask here by line 755 above.
We're checking this in mctp_message_tx_on_bus(), so we should remove the check here.

I think we get the advantage of returning early if we do it here (without doing a find_bus_for_eid). A redundant check in mctp_message_tx_on_bus() is required since it can be invoked from mctp_rx (if ROUTE_BRIDGE policy is enabled)
bit of a nit, but can we swap these two around? Again in the other test below where necessary.
This should be using one of the TO macros.
